If this has been done before, then I apologize

But basically, the point of the game is to pretend one is sitting in a class, taking a test. The test has questions on them, which must be answered in a way that makes sense, but that is not necessarily factual. For example, math questions do not actually have to be treated as 'math' questions. E.g, "Bob has 40 dollars, and bananas cost 1 dollar each. How many bananas can Bob get?"

You don't necessarily have to say '40,' you can say something dumb like "He can get as many bananas as he wants, because Bob is a banana-obsessed gunman with an 18-wheeler who is hell-bent on taking every single banana in the store."

Stuff that is technically possible, even if it's unlikely or dumb

The questions can also be scenarios or even riddles of sorts.

Rules:

-The questions have to have a loophole in them (as the title suggests) and cannot be something overly long and convoluted.

-The questions can be anything. They don't have to be math or school/work-related

-Answer the question above you, and then post your own question

I'll start:

Question #1: You're watching TV when the device turns itself off for no reason. You press the button and nothing happens. What do you do to continue watching TV?
I beat it until it works.
